message: It's hard to believe this is possible, but it obviously is now: http://www.popsci.com/technology/article/2011-03/video-new-seagull-robot-takes-and-flies-just-real-thing

Even the hummingbird has its limitations - it flies more-or-less like a helicopter. Most insects as well. Bats are unique in their ability to change direction, perch, and avoid collisions, not to mention catching flies mid-air. I'm going to look that up, as I'm sure somebody's working on it.

They've also got a flying penguin (http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jPGgl5VH5go) and a flying sting ray (http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=UxPzodKQays&feature=related).  These devices are very minimally actuated, as I understand it, so tons of ingenuity went into clever, complex mechanical engineering of the structures to create that level of life-like / fluid motion.

Yeah, I've heard about the Sting Ray and seen the pics & video of the penguin. There's something I can't put my finger on that makes this one stand out... I think it's how lifelike its flight appears, and how well it glides. I'd like to see a good life-inspired Bat robot. They're incredibly nimble and far more precise than birds. But, given their appetites, I imagine this requires far more power to achieve. Bats aren't known for their ability to glide, after all.
Yeah, saw 3 in development. Seems they're not quite there yet. Some are close, but underwhelming.
